amusingly, I hadn't defined "rep" in Arc, and never noticed until now...
I noticed. :P I exposed rep to Arc on my fork. Though, I only noticed because I was working on Arubic, and I was trying out the route of tagging Arubic stuff with custom types.
btw, when you notice bugs, feel free to add them to the readme.
move tnil to ac, rename to ar-tnil: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/512c63b38ac2f7cf2d2aedf484749f7a725bff21
move no? and true? to ac; rename to ar-no and ar-true: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/553942df1c805e78349b81af228bd4d4805db5cb
move deep-fromarc to ac; rename to ar-deep-fromarc: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/4f871c115713b83d99dd298f3b3f773ef4c289fb
Tests have gotten a lot slower since I started moving things to ac, I'll have to look into that.
Hmm, I'm seeing a 40% increase when I moved apply to ac.

Another slowdown when I moved "is" to ac, another bump when I moved tnil, maybe a bit of a slowdown when I moved car and cdr, and a further slowdown when I moved ar-no and ar-true.  My hypothesis: I shouldn't be calling namespace-variable-value at runtime.

performance improvement: avoid calling namespace-variable-value in ar-deep-fromarc, cadr, cddr, ar-true, map1, is, and apply: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/b13eaa6ff748551187cc8820d030df4e3831d7f8
arc-test is now only running twice as slow as before instead of five times as slow :), so it's looking promising
remove the old non-working code for table based global variables: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/97a1dd734e790097f67346d22e293ce271021c3f
use ar-def for is2 and is: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/89509d3d49d7bdaf5b3942619345f9b59c3c0ece

On my laptop, running arc-test used to take 11.6 seconds before I started moving things out of ar (https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/b893a7e88e5bd2b3ad59d95afb05a14047bb58ca); and it now takes 16.2 seconds.  This is a lot better than it was before I started to use ar-def to avoid calls to namespace-variable-value at runtime, but still taking 40% more time to run the test.

Now only 15% more time to run arc-test.ss, which I'm going to call good enough for now.  a) the performance of running tests isn't necessarily indicative of the performance of running programs; b) there probably are lots of performance tweaks we can make when we get to that point.

And, I hope, easier to hack, since the global namespace is now always available.

I think I've gone as far as I can with the ar-def conversion with the current test framework; so my next step will be to start moving ac definitions out to a file which is loaded where they can be tested more easily.  (Things will be messy for a while).

Perhaps you disagree with my exact approach, perhaps you would prefer for scripting to be in a separate file (like script-arc for instance), and that's okay, but why throw the baby out with the bathwater? It should be easy enough to refactor my code to do what you want, which is nice because my code actually does more than yours.
Question: why're you redoing work I already did in my fork? Like the script stuff (which I had already sorted out a lot of stuff, fixed bugs, etc.)

To add something to the base ar branch:

1) fork it

2) make a commit to the fork containing just the change you want to make

3) click "Pull Request" in GitHub (http://help.github.com/pull-requests/)

of course, in theory either one of us could notice something in Arubic that can or should be in the base ar branch; in practice you're probably going to be a lot better at than I am, if only because you know which parts of your branch are specific to Arubic.

None of my fork (at least the public part) is specific to Arubic, since I've been very careful to only add in things that I think would be useful to ar in general. Also, I did try a pull request earlier, but got an error. I'll try again.
(Also, like half of the stuff is me porting tests over to my Python-style tester, so you can just ignore the files in the "tests/" subdirectory, if you want)
Ah, I misunderstood.  I thought your branch was an implementation of Arubic.  I'll pay more attention then ^_^
This is going to take me a while to work through.  Are there any particular merges that you think would be most useful to do first?
Aaand pull request sent. Good that it didn't error this time.

By the way, there is *one* merge in particular that would have immediate benefit:

https://github.com/Pauan/ar/commit/ae4753641ccdc5c7e01a1abb0687c966d586ca6f

Those are the only changes to ac.ss, but it implements some nice stuff like coerce to fn and special forms being gensyms.

Uh, not really. They all kinda go together, you know? If you're feeling risky, you can just have my changes obliterate yours, since I *did* keep up to date with ar. But yeah, sorry, I got kinda carried away working on stuff. I can wait, it's not a big rush or anything, since I can just keep working on my fork, right?

Fix bug with (read "[3]").
Remove unnecessary readtable parameterization from racket-eval.
Merge from https://github.com/Pauan/ar/commit/ae4753641ccdc5c7e01a1abb0687c966d586ca6f:

https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/28ecb2b9a3c5bc1542479bc2fad35e996782ce41
(well, one of the reasons, anyways) is there a reason you went with obscure-name rather than gensyms?
Hey, uh, that's kinda the reason for me using gensyms, like with fn and stuff, so why not do that?
Ah, alright, that's fine. I was just curious if there was any particular reason.

I was in a hurry because I had to get something working.  And I haven't had a chance to think about gensyms yet.  And I think I'll be able to come up with a better way of having the Arc compiler generate a Racket null anyway.

bit of confusion in terminology here: there's "ar", my project which creates an environment that languages such as Arc can be loaded in; and then there's ar the "Arc runtime", the component of Arc which defines its primitive runtime functions.

Thank you for consolidating the tests a bit! Figuring out where to add my ssyntax tests felt a bit trickier than it had to be. ^_^

Welcome.  In the middle of a project like this there parts that are starting to work and many other parts that are still awful, and I mostly try to work on whatever seems to be the most terrible at the moment :)
initial stab at a dependency loader: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/a33b8b6add76ebc76a7ca1daa0001cc73834bc1b

"bit of confusion in terminology here: there's "ar", my project which [...]"

Yes, and when I feel like being pedantic, I call them "ar" and "Arc/ar" respectively, but saying Arc/ar all the time is annoying, so when I'm feeling more informal, I'll just shorten it to "ar" since right now "ar" only has Arc by default.

I am aware that technically ar is trying to be a runtime that can load multiple languages, but it's just so much easier (and shorter) to use ar as an alias for Arc/ar. :P Not sure what I'll do when ar actually starts to support non-Arc languages, though... maybe I'll be forced to use Arc/ar all the time.
moving towards being able to load ac as a dependency, but that's probably all I'm going to have time to do tonight
auto load ac as a dependency: https://github.com/awwx/ar/commit/45cc6a4602eb38cb02fad7531587a886cd6082bb

re "ar" vs "Arc/ar": interestingly, Arc/ar and Arc/ac used to need to be loaded in different ways ("ar.ail" as Racket code, "ac.arc" as Arc code), but now with the progressive enhancement of the loader both can be loaded as Arc code... and ar.arc wouldn't be very large if we moved coerce and + into Arc... which means we might merge ar.arc into ac.arc at some point perhaps.

Hmm, is it a good idea to test something using a test framework that relies on it anyway? Well, if it breaks, at least it's sure to break spectacularly....
You can use an older, working version of ar to test a newer (perhaps speculative, or experimental) version.
hmm, doing a merge shows the history which is good, but what is lost is seeing the actual change that was checked in as a single unit... thus I manually put the diff in a gist.
oops, I messed up print-name.  my bad.

This time I used "git cherry-pick --no-commit" to pull the change so that I could make a single commit with my changes as a unit... I think this works better for me, at least until we figure a way to get github to show the actual change that I committed.
